table.description: Contains up to one row of Demographic data for each Subject combination.

column.description: Subject identifier
Subject classification for species using informal taxonomy.
Subject classification for subspecies using informal taxonomy.
Subject classification by self report for sex/gender. Defined as sex at birth.
Subject classification by self report of the gender with which the subject identifies.
Subject classification indicating a cohort or group of subjects with shared characteristics.
Subject classification by self-report for race categories as defined by NIH OMB standards.
Subject classification by self-report for ethnicity categories as defined by NIH OMB standards.
Subject classification for location by country. Derived from location of clinical site where subject enrolled in study.
Subject classification for circumcision status at enrollment. Depending on study, the status is either self-reported or assessed by clinician.
Subject Body Mass Index (BMI) at enrollment. BMI is defined as the body mass divided by the square of the body height represented in kg/m2.
Subject BMI category at enrollment. Underweight: < 18.5; 18.5 – 24.9: Normal Weight; 25.0 – 29.9: Overweight; >= 30.0: Obese.
Subject classification for age using pre-defined age ranges.
Subject age at enrollment. Depending on study, the value is either a self-reported age at time of enrollment or calculated from date of birth.
Study protocol
Standard label composed of network and the unique ID number for the study.
Study Short Name.
The official study start date assigned by the network (e.g. date of study registration).
The date when the first subject is enrolled (i.e. received first injection) in the study. For human subject studies only.
The date when the last subject completes final study visit. For human subject studies only.
For CAVD: 90-day closeout is complete. For HVTN: "Manuscript Published or Not Publishable" milestone.
The primary network for which the study was conducted.
Primary investigator name for the study.
The primary strategy the study was conducted with.
Target study day for the last vaccination to be administered for the treatment arm.
Study classification indicating the type of trial design used in the study (e.g. preclinical, Phase I, or Phase II).

A set of treatment groups and/or cohorts grouped within a study as defined in the schema. Typcially, used to indicate phases of a study such as the main study vs an extension/amendment, or to define cohorts for analysis such as product or regimen comparisons. Parts may or may not be sequentially enrolled.
A set of treatment arms grouped within a study as defined in the schema. Typcially, used to indicate the schedule of product administration, assessments, and other study procedures.
Treatment arm assigned to study subjects which indicates the visit schedule and specific product, doses, and routes to be administered during the study.
A brief summary of information about the assigned treatment arm, including the study part, group, vaccinee/placebo, and products administered.
A coded description of the product adminstration regimen indicating both product and timing e.g., DDMM to indicate a regimen where 2 DNA prime vaccinations followed by 2 MVA boost vaccinations.
Study classification indicating if subjects in the treatment arm will receive vaccine or placebo.
Classification of product combinations indicating which classes of products where administered in the study.
Classification of product combinations indicating which products where administered in the study.

table.description: Contains up to one row of ICS (Intracellular Cytokine Staining) data for each Subject/Visit combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
Study protocol
Name identifying assay
Defines the level at which the magnitude or response has been summarized (i.e. summarized at the protein panel or protein level).
Type of cell or cell subset assessed for antigen-stimulated expression of peptide(s). This cell type is usually CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, but other cell types can also be assessed.
Name of cell or cell subset assessed for antigen-stimulated expression of peptide(s). This cell type is usually CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, but other cell types can also be assessed.
The name of the antigen or stimulant being tested as reported by the lab in the assay dataset.
The standardized term for the type of antigen or stimulant (e.g. peptide pool, protein, panel) being tested.
The name of the peptide pool for which a magnitude and response call are calculated.

The name of the gene-based subpanel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. Depending on how the individual peptide pools are constructed, the subpanel magnitude may be the sum of the magnitudes fo the constituent peptide pools (for cases where there is no overlap between pools) or the maximum magnitude of the constituent peptide pools (for cases where the pools overlap).

The name of the panel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. The magnitude and response calls are the maximum of the values of magnitude and response for the gene-based sub-panels making up the panel.
The type of specimen used in the assay. For ICS, this is generally PBMC, but may also be mucosal specimens.
The name of the marker assessed, such as IL-2 (cytokine) or Granzyme-B (protease).
The type of functional marker expressed by the ICS assay. This is usually a cytokine, but it can also include cell-surface markers, expressed proteases, and other molecules.
The clade (gene subtype) to which the antigen is most closely aligned. The clade may be a circulating type or a laboratory consensus or global clade.
Indicates if the interactive part of the antigen was designed to match the immunogen in the vaccine.
Response call comparing cell expression in stimulated versus unstimulated cells. Calculation method may vary (e.g. Fisher's Exact Test or MIMOSA).
Percent of cells expressing the functional marker of interest in response to antigen stimulation.
Percent of cells expressing the functional marker of interest in response to antigen stimulation. Adjusted for background (unstimulated) expression.
Percent of cells expressing the functional marker of interest in the absence of antigen stimulation.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
Unique ID assigned to the experiment design of the assay for tracking purposes.
Details regarding the provenance of the assay results.
Method used to calculate the response call (e.g. Fisher's Exact Test or MIMOSA).
Indicates if the antigen is a negative control.
Indicates which antigens were inlcuded in the aggregated magnitudes and response calls.

A calculated score that summarizes a subject’s entire Ag-specific polyfunctional profile into a single numerical value. The functionality score is the proportion of Ag-specific subsets detected among all possible ones.
A calculated score that summarizes a subject’s entire Ag-specific polyfunctional profile into a single numerical value, weighing the different subsets by their degree of functionality

table.description: Contains up to one row of ELISPOT (Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSpot) data for each Subject/Visit combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
Study protocol
Name identifying assay
Defines the level at which the magnitude or response has been summarized (i.e. summarized at the panel or sub-panel level).
The name of the antigen being tested as reported by the lab in the assay dataset.
The standardized term for the type of antigen (e.g. peptide pool, protein, panel) being tested.
The name of the peptide pool for which a magnitude and response call are calculated.

The name of the gene-based subpanel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. Depending on how the individual peptide pools are constructed, the subpanel magnitude may be the sum of the magnitudes fo the constituent peptide pools (for cases where there is no overlap between pools) or the maximum magnitude of the constituent peptide pools (for cases where the pools overlap).

The name of the panel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. The magnitude and response calls are the maximum of the values of magnitude and response for thegene-based sub-panels making up the panel.
A combination of protein panel and protein used for filtering.
A combination of protein panel, protein, and peptide pool used for filtering.
The clade (gene subtype) to which the antigen is most closely aligned. The clade may be a circulating type or a laboratory consensus or global clade.
Type of cell or cell subset assessed for antigen-stimulated expression of peptide(s). This cell type is usually CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, but other cell types can also be assessed.
Name of cell or cell subset assessed for antigen-stimulated expression of peptide(s). This cell type is usually CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, but other cell types can also be assessed.
Indicates if the interactive part of the antigen was designed to match the immunogen in the vaccine.
The type of specimen used in the assay.
The name of the marker assessed, (IFNg, cytokine).
The type of functional marker expressed by the assay (i.e. cytokine).
Indicates if response was detected as calculated using bootstrap response call.
Mean Number of Spot-forming Cells (SFC) in response to antigen stimulation, adjusted for number of spot forming cells without antigen stimulation.
Mean Number of Spot-forming Cells (SFC) in the absence of antigen stimulation.
Mean Number of Spot-forming Cells (SFC) in response to antigen stimulation.
Details regarding the provenance of the assay results.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
Unique ID assigned to the experiment design of the assay for tracking purposes.

table.description: Contains up to one row of NAb (Neutralizing antibody) data for each Subject/Visit combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
Study protocol
Name identifying assay
Defines the level at which the magnitude or response has been summarized (e.g. summarized at the isolate level).
The type of specimen used in the assay. For nAb assays, this is generally serum or plasma.
The name of the antigen (virus) being tested.
The standardized term for the type of virus used in the construction of the nAb antigen.
The term for the virus (antigen) being tested.
The type of virus used in the construction of the nAb antigen.
The amino acid sequence inserted in the virus construct.
The clade (gene subtype) of the virus (antigen) being tested.
A classification specific to HIV NAb assay design, in which an antigen is assessed for its ease of neutralization (1=most easily neutralized, 3=least easily neutralized)
A combination of neutralization tier, antigen clade, and virus used for filtering.
The cell line used in the assay to determine infection (lack of neutralization). Generally TZM-bl or A3R5, but can also be other cell lines or non-engineered cells.
Indicates the initial specimen dilution.
The half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50).
The 80% maximal inhibitory concentration (IC80).
The adjusted value of 50% maximal inhibitory dilution (ID50).
The adjusted value of 80% maximal inhibitory dilution (ID80).
Indicates if neutralization is detected based on ID50 titer.
Indicates if neutralization is detected based on ID80 titer.
Indicates if neutralization is detected.
Details regarding the provenance of the assay results.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
Unique ID assigned to the experiment design of the assay for tracking purposes.
The slope calculated using the difference between 50% and 80% neutralization.
Indicates if the interactive part of the antigen was designed to match the immunogen in the vaccine.

table.description: Contains up to one row of BAMA (Binding Ab multiplex assay) data for each Subject/Visit combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
The type of specimen used in the assay
Study protocol
Name identifying assay
The name of the antigen being tested as reported by the lab in the assay dataset.
The standardized term for the type of antigen (e.g. protein) being tested.

The name of the proteins for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. Depending on how the individual peptide pools are constructed, the protein magnitude may be the sum of the magnitudes fo the constituent peptide pools (for cases where there is no overlap between pools) or the maximum magnitude of the constituent peptide pools (for cases where the pools overlap).

The name of the panel of proteins for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. The magnitude and response calls are the maximum of the values of magnitude and response for the proteins making up the panel.
The binding anitbody isotype that is quantified by the assay.
The clade (gene subtype) to which the antigen is most closely aligned. The clade may be a circulating type or a laboratory consensus or global clade.
Indicates if the interactive part of the antigen was designed to match the immunogen in the vaccine
The instrument on which the assay was performed. This affects the dynamic range of the readout, and the comparability of magnitude across instruments.
Response call calculated using standard criteria across studies.
Indicates the initial specimen dilution.

The difference between the Median Fluorescence Intensity (MFI) of antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads adjusted to subtract background (Magnitude (mfi) - Background subtracted from raw) and the maximum MFI of antibody-binding to non-conjugated (blank) beads adjusted to subtract background (Magnitude (mfi)-Background subtracted from blank).

Mean Fluorescence Intensity of beads indicating antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads, adjusted for mean Fluorescence Intensity of antibody-binding to non-specific (non-conjugated) beads at baseline.
Median Fluorescence Intensity of antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads.
Mean Fluorescence Intensity of beads indicating antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads at baseline.
Median Fluorescence Intensity of antibody-binding to non-conjugated (blank) beads.
Mean Fluorescence Intensity of antibody-binding to blank beads at baseline.
Median Fluorescence Intensity of antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads, adjusted to subtract background.
Median Fluorescence Intensity of antibody-binding to non-conjugated (blank) beads adjusted to subtract background.
The area under the titration curve as calculated for VISC analysis. Method may vary across studies.
Details regarding the provenance of the assay results.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
Unique ID assigned to the experiment design of the assay for tracking purposes.
Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Unique ID assigned to the study by the network indicating the main study (e.g. CAVD 583)
Unique ID assigned to an individual mAb or mixture of mAbs.
Unique ID assigned to the mAb (often recoded) being tested in a given study.
The cell line used in the assay to determine infection (lack of neutralization). Generally TZM-bl.
The short name identifying the assay
Defines the level at which the magnitude or response has been summarized (i.e. summarized at the across dilutions).
The clade (gene subtype) of the virus (antigen) being tested.

A classification specific to HIV NAb assay design, in which an antigen is assessed for its ease of neutralization (1=most easily neutralized, 3=least easily neutralized). As indicated in the master virus list.
The dilution at which the virus is being tested.
The type of specimen used in the assay. For nAb assays, this is generally serum or plasma.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
The standardized name of the virus being tested - as indicated in the master virus list.
The concated tier-clade-virus value for filtering.
The type of virus used in the construction of the nAb antigen.
Indicates the initial specimen concentration
The number of times the mAb has been diluted from the initial concentration to reach the mAb concentration being tested.
Indicates a unique set of records with the same combination of study mAb, virus, mAb concentration, target cell, and lab code. Used for plotting neutralization curves.

The concentration of the specimen (mab) being tested in a given well on a plate. The initial concentration of each specimen is reduced by the dilution factor (3). Typically, a total of 8 concentrations are tested for each specimen (mab).
The units in which the concentration is measured (ug/mL)

The minimum concentration of a given specimen (mab) being tested across all wells for that specimen on a given plate. The initial concentration of each specimen is reduced by the dilution factor (3). Typically, a total of 8 concentrations are tested for each specimen (mab). The minimum concentration equals the initial concentration.

The maximum concentration of a given specimen (mab) being tested across all wells for that specimen on a given plate. The initial concentration of each specimen is reduced by the dilution factor (3). Typically, a total of 8 concentrations are tested for each specimen (mab). The maximum concentration equals the last dilution made on the plate.
The minimum well value (luminescence?) across replicates/duplicates for each unique assay_id-run-plate_number-specimen_id-dilution)
The maximum well value (luminescence?) across replicates/duplicates for each unique assay_id-run-plate_number-specimen_id-dilution)
The mean of the well values (luminescence?) across replicates/duplicates for each unique assay_id-run-plate_number-specimen_id-dilution)
The standard deviation around the mean of the well values (luminscence?) across replicates/duplicates for each unique assay_id-run-plate_number-specimen_id-dilution)

Represents the percent of virus neutralized by the specimen at a specific dilution. The percent neutralization is calculated using the mean well value (luminiscence?) of each unique assay_id-run-plate_number-specimen_id-dilution, where the mean is calculated across 1 or more replicates/duplicates (ReplicateNumber).

Represents a range around the percent neutralization. The plus/minus is calculated by taking the standard deviation of the well data for that sample/dilution group and dividing it by the control range for the plate. The control range is mean of the virus control wells minus the mean of the cell control wells.
The adjusted curve-based value of 50% maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50)
The adjusted curve-based value of 80% maximal inhibitory concentration (IC80)
The adjusted point-based value of 50% maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50)
The adjusted point-based value of 80% maximal inhibitory concentration (IC80)
Indicates if neutralization is detected at this concentration.
Indicates if neutralization is detected at this concentration.
The slope of the dose–response curve.
Curve fit parameter - Minimum
Curve fit parameter - Maximum
Curve fit parameter - Asymmetry
Curve fit parameter - Slope
Curve fit parameter - Inflection point
Curve fit error
Indicates if the interactive part of the antigen was designed to match the immunogen in the vaccine

table.description: Contains up to one row of PKMAb (Pharmacokinetics Monoclonal Antibody) data for each Subject/VisitTime combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
Study protocol
Unique ID assigned to the study visit.
Description of the study visit.
Study hours after initial infusion
Study hours after most recent infusion
The assay used to measure the mAb concentration.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
The type of specimen used in the assay.
Name identifying assay
Defines the level at which the magnitude or response has been summarized (e.g. summarized at the isolate level).
Unique ID assigned to the mAb (often recoded) being tested in a given study.
MAb or Mixture Standardized Name.
Unique ID assigned to an individual mAb or mixture of mAbs.
The antibody concentration measured at a given timepoint.
The unit of the concentration measured.
